SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences others may prove impractical for you to answer, so don't worry about having blank spaces. Use "etc." instead of "insert here," do not worry about being able to answer all the questions. Give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Diets: What Did They Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires available
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Very much interested in my Emigration.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Between Liverpool and Preston I traveled with my wife and two children. We arrived at Preston on the 25th of June, 1879.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

My wife came by CPR freight train while I came by horse and cart.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents, or other excitement etc.)

They had to keep me from going to preachers. The station agent tried to have me miss the train when the train was ready to pull out. The Railway from Regina to Prince Albert was completed in 1879, the same year.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed for a time with Edgar and his wife five miles east of Saskatoon. Later we moved to a neighbor's place near the town of Saskatoon.

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Our home has been continuous at least fifteen years from Saskatoon.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked on my father's farm until 1879. My mother farmed on Thompson's farm until 1879. My brother farmed on Thompson's farm until 1879. My wife farmed on Thompson's farm until 1879.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Very much interested in my Emigration.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Between Edmonton and Calgary we traveled by ourselves. We came by way of Edmonton and Calgary. We traveled by train from Edmonton to Calgary.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

My wife came by CPR freight train. She traveled with a team of horses and mules.

14. What obstacles of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences etc.)

They had to cross a river near the town of Red Deer. They also had to cross a river near the town of Red Deer.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed for a time with Mr. and Mrs. Clements. They lived near the town of Red Deer.

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Our home has been near the town of Red Deer.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked on a farm until 1898. My wife was a housewife.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A NOTE OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON COMPLETING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to "rehash" a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may apply to those of your family or friends. If there is not enough space to answer the questions, feel free to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:

- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Transmission of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office and the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Mainly reading the Grain and Homestead Agricultural Exhibitions held at Regina in 1887. I also went from immigration literature and a map of the western Prairies with the Canadian Pacific Railway partly completed.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They were very much against me leaving our rural breaking and farming land during the war.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? My wife and I traveled together from Liverpool, England, to Quebec, Montreal, and then to Edmonton, Alberta.

13. What mode of transportation did you use? We traveled by train from Liverpool to Liverpool, Ontario, and then by boat to Quebec City. From Quebec City, we took the train to Montreal, where we boarded another train to Edmonton.

14. What challenges of the journey did you experience? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other problems.) We encountered many challenges, including meeting with Indians along the way and dealing with accidents and delays.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We stayed at the Red Hat Hotel in Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? We settled on a homestead near Saskatoon.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. We lived in our home in Regina until 1921.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

19. Describe the homestead you worked at. It was located near Saskatoon, and we worked hard to make it productive.

20. Any other comments or observations about your experiences in Western Canada? We enjoyed our time there and learned a lot about farming and homesteading.

Landlordism but soon into a system of organized socialism under the leadership of Mr. Macdonald, who became Premier of Canada. In conclusion, the family faced many challenges during their time in Saskatchewan, but they persevered and built a successful farm.
